Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: sexual-explicit and non-sexual-explicit. A comment is considered sexual-explicit if it explicitly portrays sexual matters.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: President lied under oath about consensual sex...
Not the same thing as rape.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment explicitly mentions "consensual sex" and "rape", and thus is sexual-explicit.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Yea its your pals choppin heads off. Take em all and leave my country
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but does not portray sexual matters.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: It's horrible, isn't it?  It had blood coming out of its eyes.  Blood coming out of its wherever.  Terrible.
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment is violent but does not portray sexual matters
This comment contains explicit language of sexual matters and should be considered sexual-explicit, althought the intent might of the comment might differ.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: This is an interesting question and the answer is complex.  If availability of funds is unlimited then clearly spending any amount to reduce any bad thing is warranted.  In reality, resources are limited and decisions regarding optimal use of funds must be made.  For every decision to spend money on one thing, we spend less on something else.  In absolute terms, terrorist murder comprises a very small percentage of total murders, yet we spend far more money fighting terrorism than we do fighting other murder.  To do so is irrational, but that is who we are.  

More generally, I think that murder is reduced not through conviction and sentencing, but through broad public acceptance and support of the value of human life.  When we as a society treat people as disposable, dehumanize them, call them pond scum, drop bombs on them, or kill them via police, we teach individuals that it is okay to solve personal problems through murder, robbery, etc.  We reap the fruit of what we sow.

Comment: Clearly they offered him a job for stepping aside. Whether that is a crime or not, was up to the judge to decide and it seems that he did not think it was a criminal offence. End of story........except that this is a great example of what is wrong with our current electoral system. 
The basis of a parliamentary democracy used to be that candidates (all parties) were elected by the membership of that party in their riding. If elected, that candidate would be expected in part to champion the interests of  those in the riding. 
Today it seems that candidates are either appointed by the party or are elected as a result of mass last minute sign ups of new members - worryingly, in many cases those new members often being signed up on the basis of their race or religion to support a candidate of their same race or religion.  
We don’t need to change our electoral system - simply to restore the current one to working order.

Comment: Let's use this analogy:

There is a baker who is a Black Orthodox Jew. Three customers (a Neo-Nazi, a KKK, and a gay person) come in, separately, and they select items he has for sale and he rings up their individual purchases. 
-
Is there any form of discrimination there? No.
-
The next day, those same three customers return, separately, and they each ask the Black Jewish baker to decorate a cake they want to buy. The Neo-Nazi wants a cake decorated with swastikas and a picture of Hitler; the KKK wants the cake decorated showing a man being lynched; the gay person wants a same-sex wedding cake. He respectfully declines all three requests.
-
Is there any form of discrimination there, and if so, exactly what is being discriminated against?
-
"Yes," there might to some sort of "discrimination"....but what is being "discriminated" is the "artwork" he is being asked to create with his artistic talents.
-
He cannot discriminate against "people," but "offensive artwork" is not "people."

Comment: and were proud of what they had achieved.

That pride was usually something new for them and new for their parents. It was also vital to their self-esteem (including that of their parents): the kids had long seen themselves as stupid, a 'bad kid', a troublemaker and the parents often felt like they were poor parents. 

Kids aren't stupid: they know when something is meeting their needs and when it isn't. They knew that punching numbers into a calculator and writing the answers onto a photocopied sheet was busy-work. They also knew that after months & years of doing it, they still could not solve real-life problems that involved even rudimentary calculations.

Bottom line: they learned the basic operations and eventually came to understand how & when to apply them, whether their answer was at all reasonable, etc. Many of them eventually conceded that they had come to like math.

All of which led to improved attitudes, improved attendance and greatly improved behaviour.

Comment: Well then Phil, you must be opposed to the Supreme Court interpreting the First Amendment to mean that corporations possess a separate freedom of speech, and that money is speech. Right? Our Constitution isn't a roadmap or an operators manual giving specific instructions about how to do everything. Nobody in 1788 had any idea, for instance, that we would need regulation of radio spectra. Our Constitution sets broad goals and divides powers among the federal government and the states, and defines broadly the establishment of an Executive, a Legislative body, and a Judicial hierarchy. If our Constitution didn't need daily interpretation we would have no need for the Judicial. Without the Judicial the Executive would usurp all powers, and we don't want that, do we. Right now we are seeing that check and balance impeding the raw will of our president. It's a great show and we need to pay less attention to Trump's absurd theatrics and keep our eyes on the real show.

Jesus clearly did not teach that we are saved by following the law (Google "Matthew 5:18 commentary" if that's one verse you're getting at, https://www.gci.org/bible/matthew517 for example); we get right with God, forgiven, through faith in Christ's finished work on the cross that paid the price for our sins, but, genuine saving faith will have as part of it a conviction of the ugliness of our sin and the need to turn away from it - repentance (required by God; you can't ask for forgiveness and then continue doing those very same things), and Christ's lordship, without which we can't live a life pleasing to God. Comment: 1) France is arguably the country that most uses and relies on nuclear energy. 76% of its electricity comes from nuclear fission. If you accept that climate change is real then warmer climates and lower water levels in rivers is going to be a continuing problem for them, and elsewhere. 

2) Regulation in the case of a nuclear power plant is a Very Good Thing. The only reason that nuclear energy is the safest (!) form of energy today - killing less people than most other renewables - is because of these regulations. And yet we still get disasters like Fukushima, Three Mile Island, and Chernobyl. It's thanks to these regulations that since the late 1980s the number of nuclear accidents has significantly dropped. People get emotional because it's scary.

Another argument against nuclear and for other forms of renewables is exactly that - renewables are decentralized and as such less likely to be susceptible to state oversight and overreach.

Comment: I'm not a scientist and have never studied the chemical compositions of either, but I've heard - from a great many people, who are far more knowledgeable on the subject than I - that there is a significant difference between CBD hemp oil and CBD cannabis oil.  My common sense explanation is that there must be a difference if one is permissible through USDA (CBD hemp oil) and the other isn't (CBD cannabis oil).  
 
With one lab and regulations/processes still tied up in the long halls of bureaucracy, I don't suspect that local dispensaries have had an opportunity to test their cannabis and manufactured cannabis products.  Hawai'i law requires that manufactured cannabis products be permitted and I have yet to see the DOH rules that provide those permits/permissible uses.   

I don't think you give enough credit to locals, who have had to tap into their own resourcefulness for medical cannabis for - arguably - a great many decades.  You also don't need a dispensary for CBD hemp oil.

Hillary is going to be a successful disaster of a president: her time, like her husband's, will be characterized by optimism and economic expansion, maybe even by a modicum of actual law-making.   The phrase "trickle-down" won't be heard, but the idea will rule.  As a result, today's losers (not in Trump's sense) will be worse off at the end of her time than they are now.

These are the times that try men's souls: vote against Trump and save yours.

Comment: AGW is nothing but FRAUD only the mentally challenged believe in.

A simple greenhouse test:

- 20x20x8' greenhouse has 3,200 cubic feet
- The amount of CO2 is 1.28 cubic feet
- Does any grown sane adult honestly believe adding or removing 1 cubic foot of CO2 from the greenhouse is going to magically change the temperature by 2C?

If this was true why would anyone need to pay for energy to heat their house? All they would need to do is put a clear bubble on their roof and fill it with 100% CO2.

- The amount of CO2 increase since 1960 is equal to 7x7x7" in the greenhouse. Does anyone think this makes a difference?

- The fact is 224 cubic feet of CO2 is required to make the greenhouse temperature rise by 1C, about 70,000 PPM.

MSM and governments are scam artists, brainwashing the ignorant masses with fairy tales while they are taxed into oblivion.

Comment: I'm against the motion M-103 because of the inclusion, and because of the irrational resistance to removing, the word Islamophobia from the motion. Islamophobia, which is not defined in the motion, could mean simply a dislike of the religion of Islam, or a dislike of certain aspects of the religion of Islam. Should a legitimate and critical opinion about a religion, or about certain aspects of a religion, be condemned along with racism or bigotry, which are both unambiguously undesirable attitudes about or towards other people?

For example, a person may feel that the Islamic burqa is an obstacle to integration in society, or they may feel it is discriminatory against women and girls. Right or wrong, should this be called Islamophobia, and, more to the point, should this person be condemned and put in the same bucket as racists and bigots?

Comment: I returned to some of my favorite hunting places, places we used to spend a day hiking into.

Today all those places are trashed.  

Four wheelers and buggies have carved dual muddy ditches across swamps and muskeg, making it easy for slobs to haul in 'supplies'.  (…mostly beer, liquor, canned food, judging by the leavings.)

Garbage, broken bottles, trash and toilet paper wads spreads outwards in rings around each of the old campsites.  

Trees are all shot up or cut down, any branches at arms reach are pulled off the standing trees that are left.

 It looks like a herd of goats fed on anything they can reach, but no, it's humans.  They stripped the area and left their waste and their trash.

They drove their trucks with their multi-vehicle trailers to the trailheads and unloaded their machines so they could ride to the campsites.

Real outdoorsmen.  

Magical, returning to those old hunting grounds.  Just magical.

Comment: It's a sad situation.

Full disclosure, I used to work in film and TV production.

What I learned is that Canadian broadcasters (and film distributors) couldn't care less about domestic content - at least in English Canada. French Canada is a different and  happier story. 

Canadian broadcasters have historically made their money by paying almost nothing for US shows and even substituting Canadian commercials on US cable channels. They never had to make anything that anyone really wanted to watch. The cost of Canadian content was just a cost of doing business. It was nothing more than an annoying tax to them. The internet has changed all that.

Shame on them. Let them die. We need a completely new industry. Let's embrace the internet and let Bell, Corus and the rest of them stand at the sidelines and cry.

Comment: GBA: Calling someone a hypocrite is just an ad hominem attack, saying that they are purposely ignoring the other side which is also "bad". Here are the problems with this approach:
1. It may be true that one is a hypocrite. But all that says is "you do it too". It does not negate the original argument or claim.
2. By saying the other side did it too and you are ignoring that, you are saying the other side it bad too. In other words, in this case you are agreeing that Trump is like Obama and Holder.
3. To call someone a hypocrite means that the person making the claim is no a hypocrite. Otherwise, if they have been a hypocrite, then they are calling others hypocrites when they are one themselves. That is being hypocritical!

I don't know why using tu quoque is so popular with conservatives. I suspect is it because they tend to believe in the bad seed, and hypocrites, having sin, cannot cast the first stone.
Your logical fallacy: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tu_quoque

Comment: Can't let this go.  Have responded to 2-3 other comments, but this one's mine: the problem may not be "sexism." Like the Science Minister, I'll use my own experience to bolster that claim. Years ago, when I was young and silly, I wanted to write a book--had to write in NOW.  Needed time. Problem: had a full-time job.  So, went to my boss and I said, "I need 6 months off to write this book--hey, I don't expect pay while I'm away (wasn't THAT silly).  So.  Deal?  I come back in the fall?"  He laughed. He said, "go ahead--but you leave? No guarantees."

It wasn't sexism--I'm male, he was male. But it's the SYSTEM, see?  Can't always make "system" work for you, because YOU work for the "system." Women have done well, ie.: maternity leave. Comment: I don't think there is anything wrong with acknowledging the cultural losses suffered by indigenous people resulting from what I'll call the process of discovery and acquisition. Its actually quite heartbreaking. (Drums of Diomede is a good book for perspective). I am white and I grew up in the Alaska bush.  Its a misguided idea to think that there is any need for "formulating a way to help Alaska Native culture rebound as a proud people" and I'd go as far as to say that statement is pretty harsh. Their cultural loss is staggering. Their generational cultural loss is immeasurable. There is no going back - only forward.  I learned young that "proud" is not a word I should use to describe the Alaska native - in fact, it's a bit of an insult. They are strong, intuitive, intelligent, focused, amazingly and instinctively tuned into the natural world. My experience is that they have a death grip on their culture.  Suggesting that they need help with it is a statement of ignorance.

Comment: Klastri, you and your group of lawyers apparently do not understand that people with mental disorders routinely are disqualified for military service. Transgenders suffer from “gender dysphoria,” formerly known as “gender identity disorder,” which is classified as a mental disorder by the American Psychiatric Association. People with gender dysphoria typically suffer from stress, anxiety and depression, which are disqualifiers for enlistment and commissioning in the military and are disqualifiers for continuing on active duty. Military personnel diagnosed with these disorders while on active duty normally are discharged as unfit.   It makes absolutely no sense to knowingly allow people with disqualifying mental disorders to join the military and then burden the military with treating their disorders and even provide them with tax-payer funded sex reassignment surgery.

Comment: How can we go on thinking in the same way? Oscar Wilde may have accidentally answered this: stupidity. If I'm recalling correctly, Oscar suggested this singularly human quality as not just episodic, but as the common denominator of humanity: something so fundamental to unredeemed human nature that it could correctly be called its primary characteristic. 

History seems to bear this out: war upon war, conflict upon conflict. As for the lessons taught about their causes (the tragic flaws in human nature), quickly forgotten...if ever they were recognized at all. Old Testament prophets warned of their dire consequences if left unchecked, and Shakespeare wrote about some of these consequences. Yet, the lessons went unheeded.

The dialectical method of apprehending truth has one tragic flaw itself: it tries to transcend the affective side of human nature, which rhetoric sensibly accomodates: the power of human emotion to shape thinking, truth and knowledge.

Dialectics is for Vulcans.

Comment: The problem is the Wild Card. With 2 wild card spots, by the July 31 trade deadline every season there may only be 2-3 teams that are actually out of it. So everyone else is a "contender" to make a WC and possibly play a single playoff game. Meanwhile, serious teams like the Dodgers, Red Sox, Cubs, and Yankees build teams with a goal of winning not just a Wild Card, but the World Series. Anything less than a World Series title is failure. Eliminate the Wild Card. Add a team to each league. Form 4 Divisions in each and you will get more teams forced to spend money to build REAL teams.  Unfortunately the current system supports mediocrity and keeps fans interested and in the stands. Sadly it will never happen. Shapiro has no intention of building a World Series winning team. He is satisfied to shoot for the WC and hope for the best. And the fans are suckers.

Comment: <Only too soon, people like you will take up arms against the people who voted for the president.>
A filthy, despicable comment, even for you, and I'm going to flag it.
I hope that no-one "takes up arms" against Trump's voters or supporters, or against Trump himself.  I believe in our democratic institutions. I believe that eventually Trump will be held accountable in the democratic processes designed by the founders.
The real threat of domestic violence in the Trump years, if there is one, will arise among the relatively small number of right wing nuts -- the racists, fascists and neo-nazis who make up his political base -- who, contrary to all reason, believed that Trump could and would do what he promised.  As it dawns on them that he can't and won't, and that in most instances never intended do, the threat of right-wing violence will be very real.  Trump is a racist and a fascist, for sure -- but he's also a plutocrat who will always pursue personal aggrandizement above all else.
